dialogues.text: BRIDGET JONES enters the church. She’s older than when we last saw her, forty three to be exact, slim and elegantly dressed. She takes a deep breath and collects herself. Bridget spots Jude and Shazzer and heads towards them. Shazzer greets her with a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: SHAZZER
dialogues.text: How are you feeling, you OK?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: JUDE

dialogues.text: Is that his wife? Bridget nods.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER

dialogues.text: Wow, I did not know that.

dialogues.speaker: GINNY

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: And who can blame her? The women stare at her. BRIDGET. With all this noise and excitement.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: No, I’m okay -

dialogues.speaker: GINNY

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET

dialogues.text: Hello again.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I’m very well thank you. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I am fine.

dialogues.text: So am I. Well good bye then.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Zak, your Mum said thirty minutes. Off! Now!

dialogues.text: Right, vigilantism is no solution, let the police deal with the pimp, he’1l face a minimum of eight years in custody, assuming no previous, and how about you all sit round and watch this thing with cows in space... dialogues.text: Thanks. Bridget walks away. She stops behind a flower display and looks back at Mark patiently watching a film with five irritating children.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: See that’s the first issue right there, cows with opposable thumbs, ludicrous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dancing has started - a kind of kid/adult disco affair as children run around drunk adults. Giles & Fergus are DJin badly. The music playing is GANGNAM STYLE. Bridget - by now quite merry and wearing Poppy’s fairy wi still has the toy train wound into her hair. Mark Darcy stands aloof, a bit tortured, observing, inadvertently rapt by her. Bridget, mid dance, spots him looking alone and after a moment’s pause ‘Gangnam Styles’ over.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I'd ask you to join me, but I’m pretty sure you’re not a real Gangnam Style kind of guy.

dialogues.text: Gangnam. Bridget looks puzzled.

dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You have a train in your hair.

dialogues.text: I am aware of that.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)

NIGHT. 151 Bridget defiantly paints over Jack's graphic mural. INT. BRIDGET’S FLAT. NIGHT. 152 Back in the kitchen Bridget pours milk into the washing machine compartment and starts eating the Alpen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In another West Wing scenario, a heavily pregnant Bridget now waddling down the corridor with her researchers not s much in tow as walking incredibly slowly to match the ponderous Bridget.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: We need to give six minutes to Lu Tong, it’s a huge scoop.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Alice wants to pull the interview, she has a feature on ‘Is the world really ending on Tuesday?’

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Lu Tong is pulled over my dead body. This is a news show... Wait a second. She has to stop her West Wing walking for a little rest - is totally out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A harried and breathless Bridget bustles in to the chaoti reception area. She looks around and spots a Burmese man wearing a uniform.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Sorry, it’s chaos here today, but thank you for coming on. We’re on live in two minutes, Miranda will probably want to start with what’s happening in Naypyidaw... The Studio Guest tries to speak but Bridget hurries him along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bridget sits in the gallery. The new-look, crowd-sourced show is in play. Up on screen appears a Poonani member at press conference on the street.

dialogues.speaker: POONANI MEMBER
dialogues.text: This is a great victory for free speech. We must thank one person who was prepared to fight for us when no one else would, and we say to that person with all our hearts... ON SCREEN: The Poonani girls lifting up their t-shirts in unison revealing WE LOVE YOU MARK DARCY, QC scrawled acro their bare breasts. The crowd roars. The camera swings to Mark Darcy smiling awkwardly. The screen, now bearing Mark Darcy’s image, freezes. Bridget distracted. Her assistant nudges her.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: (barking into microphone) Miranda, you’re back on General Lu Tong. Keep pressing him. This could make the front pages, Peabody!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD FINCH
dialogues.text: He’s on the rack, tight on three, get those beads of sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda is interviewing the guest.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I’‘1l ask you again, General Lu Tong will you take responsibility for the human rights abuses perpetrated by your government?

dialogues.speaker: GUEST
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I can’t answer that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bridget is triumphant. She shouts into the earpiece.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Ha! Can’t or won’t, Lu Tong? REVEAL - Alice Peabody has sneaked in behind with an angr looking, very dignified and smartly dressed man.  SHOOTING SCRIPT. 107

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: On balance I would suggest ‘can’t’ considering I just found General Lu Tong in the lobby, and his chauffeur is currently live on air answering questions about Burmese human rights violations. Good job!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice sits at her desk opposite Richard and Bridget. The front pages of the newspaper reads “So long Lu Tong!”.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It’s actually illegal to fire somebody for being pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I’m not firing her for being pregnant. I’m firing her for gross incompetency.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD FINCH
dialogues.text: Bridget’s the beating heart of this show, why would you fire her?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: How about for interviewing a chauffeur instead of a General, publicly insulting the CEO of the London Media Show, using a TV interview to determine if a guest might be the father of her child and being responsible for broadcast of 36 bare arses.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: It’s okay Richard. I was going to quit anyway. (to Alice) Believe it or not, I was it like you when I started here, a bit chunkier maybe, and with less make up. I was going to make my mark too. But I can’t be part of your “re-branding”. I haven’t got the right haircut, and I don’t drink my cocktails out of jam jars or put photos of my lunch on instagram. It might be old fashioned to want to make something worthwhile but I'd rather be old fashioned and unemployed than be part of a show that celebrates the inane. Alice and her acolytes look at each other, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe when my son is old enough to understand, integrity will be fashionable again. Good luck and goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: 159A
dialogues.text: 160 At the door, one of Alice’s hipster assistant hands her a containing her belongings. She walks out. INT. BRIDGET’S FLAT. DAY. 159 Bridget arrives home, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Oh, dear. What have I done? She opens the fridge. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s all very well fighting for your principles when there’s no food in the fridge. Wearily, she heads back out. INT. MARK’'S HOUSE. BEDROOM. DAY 159A Mark is searching in a drawer and finds the old reindeer jumper. INT. MORRISON’S SUPERMARKET. EVENING. 160 Bridget struggling with her shopping, queues for the checkout.

dialogues.speaker: SHOPPER
dialogues.text: Is it a boy or a girl?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: It’s a boy.

dialogues.speaker: SHOPPER
dialogues.text: When's it due?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Two weeks, more or less, I think! Just as she gets to the checkout the cashier goes on her break. Bridget’s long queue shuffles over to the next til

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Is it a boy or a girl?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Boy.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: When's it due?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Um, two weeks, we think. As the cashier rings up Bridget’s purchases, another shop comes up and stares at Bridget’s bump.

dialogues.speaker: SHOPPER 2
dialogues.text: Is it -

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Boy. Two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: (talking to the next cashier) Did you read about the woman in Italy who had a baby when she was sixty-five? (turns to Bridget) That will be £40.67 please. Enter your pin. Bridget puts her card in machine, she goes blank.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I've forgotten it. Oh, God. The other customers in the queue are getting restive.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’'1l pay with cash. She fumbles in her purse, and manages to rustle up £29.60

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘1l put something back. She starts to hand back some of the items, one by one, reluctantly. The unhealthy ones first. The cashier de-sca them until the total is down to £27.60. At the last minute Bridget defiantly takes back a carton Ben and Jerry's bringing the total up to £23.10. Bridget marches out triumphantly passing a lady who is entering t shop. EXT. MARK’S HOUSE. DAY. 160A Mark is loading suitcases into a cab. Camilla exits the house. They BOTH get into the car and drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bridget is at an ATM in one of those bank lobbies, she’s still trying to remember her PIN as she attempts to get c

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: (mumbling) Birthday? INCORRECT PIN flashes.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Battle of Hastings?... First shag?..... INCORRECT PIN flashes and the machine swallows the card.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh fuck it! Bridget shuffles out.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to her tummy) Oh, my darling, I’ve gone all crap all of a sudden.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. HEATHROW AIRPORT. SAME TIME. DAY. 161A
dialogues.text: Mark and his wife enter the airport with the suitcases. T pause at the departures board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It starts to rain very hard. Bridget suddenly realizes, a the glass doors close, that she has left all of her shopp inside the bank.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Oh! Oh - come on, let’s just get home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is helping Camilla at the check-in desk. He turns around, just in time to see: Tom and Eduardo, emerging into arrivals carrying their li boy. Tom strokes his head. Eduardo fusses with the buggy. Mark watches this scene. He smiles. He thinks. Unbeknowns Camilla's observing him.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 163
dialogues.text: EXT. BRIDGET’S FLAT. DAY. 164 The rain is easing off. Bridget feels in her bag for her keys. She becomes increasingly agitated.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Oh, no! Please no. No keys. No phone.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, no! I’ve left them inside! Oh, fuckity fuckity fuckity fuck fuck. (to her tummy) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 165 She presses all the other buzzers. No answer...she slumps utterly defeated. She looks just like a crumpled old street-dweller.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, little bean. Everything that I need to call someone for help is in my bag, and I’m just too exhausted to go back and get it. I bet someone’s already tucking into my Ben and Jerry's right now. I suppose I could call Jude or Shazzer, but I can’t remember their numbers these days, and it’s probably bath time, bed time, or story time, or some other inconvenient time. And Tom's got my spares, but he’s on his way back from Ecuador, so that’s no use to us. Hmm, I wonder if Gianni’s is open? I'll just sit here for a little rest while I come up with a plan. She closes her eyes, starts to drift off. EXT. BRIDGET’S FLAT. - TRANSITION TO NIGHT 165 She comes to, looks up and thinks she’s imagining.... MAR DARCY coming round the corner. She watches him as he approaches. He gets near to her and then.... dips his hand in his pocket and gives her a tenn He then rings Bridget’s door bell.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Bridget? My god. What are you doing there? You’re all wet. You’re outside! He kneels down, helps her up.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I locked myself out. I lost my phone... and my keys... and my credit cards. Like a bloody idiot. He puts his coat round her.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: It seems I can never, ever leave this street.  SHOOTING SCRIPT. 112

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: But I thought you were back with Candida.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You know very well she’s called Camilla...

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Camilla. I came round to find you and she was there.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: She was coming to collect her things. She’s gone back to The Hague. Without a beat he wraps his scarf around his hand and pun the glass of the front door, before letting himself in. 166 INT. BRIDGET’S FLAT. NIGHT. 166 They are both now inside the flat, Bridget still reeling. Mark takes Bridget in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Look you know I find emotional declarations.... difficult, but the truth is... (a beat) Bridget?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Mmm?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Why are my trousers all warm?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Oh!! Oh!! Fuck! My waters must have broken!

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ!

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I am so sorry. I’1ll get a cloth!

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: No, no. It doesn’t matter. But you’re not due for another two or three weeks at least. A contraction. She winces.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Ooh! And that’s a contraction.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: And we are ruling out “Braxton Hicks” which tend to be longer and non - rhythmic in nature...

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Yes we bloody are. I think we should go to the hospital, quickly. Suddenly the mood is all urgent action whilst trying to maintain calm.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Absolutely!

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: We'll go in your car.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I came in a cab.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: (contraction) Oh for fuck’s sake!

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Well how was I supposed to know!?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Not you - the contractions!

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: We’ll take your car.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Can't, the keys are in my bag along with everything else. She lets out a scream.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Right. Ok. You just pant and breathe and relax and count. That’s what you’re supposed to do, right? Darcy’s phone starts to ring. Will he answer?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: 41, 42, 43, 44... Should you get that? It might be work. Mark marches over to the window and in a dramatic gesture goes to throw the phone out.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't! But he throws it out triumphantly. He’s proved himself.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Great! But we need to get a cab.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Oh shit... Can I borrow a phone? She throws him the house phone. He starts to dial.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where’s your overnight bag?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Hi there. A cab from 7A Stonier Street. A great suite of immense luggage.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good God, Bridget, it’s an overnight bag, do you really need -

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Don’t shout at me! I’ve lost count now. 48 - 49 - (another contraction) OHhhhhhhhh!

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I’m sorry but it’s painful.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: No, not you. 45 minutes for a cab, apparently it’s gridlock.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: What do we do? Mark looks out of the window and sees Gianni’s pizza van.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: We'll work something out. I’11 carry the bags. And we should call Jack. 167 INT. GIANNI’S PIZZA DELIVERY VAN. NIGHT. 167 Bridget and Mark are in Gianni’s pizza delivery van. Brid is in some pain now.

dialogues.speaker: GIANNI
dialogues.text: Don’t worry Miss Bridget, we get you there... no traffic this time of night. The van stops. Mark looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: 167A
dialogues.text: 168 GIANNI (CONT’D) A Quattro Stagione and Margherita with onion and pineapple for number 17. Gianni hands 3 pizzas to Mark, he realizes it’s futile to argue and rushes out. Gianni turns to a panting Bridget. GIANNI (CONT’D) Who has pineapple and onion - some people they a-crazy. Mark returns from his delivery and the van moves off agai GIANNI (CONT’D) Dio Mio! It’s like rush hour, Mr Mark. The van stops again.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT/EXT GIANNI’S PIZZA DELIVERY VAN. NIGHT. 167A All three in Gianni’s van. He is trying to avoid the traf He does a 3-point turn and then goes uphill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roads are indeed gridlocked and Bridget is in real pa

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: This is really happening, I’m going to be a mother, Mark. Have I left it too late...? Before Mark can answer Gianni pipes up.

dialogues.speaker: GIANNI
dialogues.text: Do not worry about the age, there was a woman in my country, she was 65 when she...

dialogues.speaker: YES
dialogues.text: They hit traffic again and come to a stand still.

dialogues.speaker: GIANNI
dialogues.text: Is unbelievable, is a bloody women’s rights march. You know I’m a big fan of women’s rights.. And their lefts. Yes Mr Mark? You get it, their lefts? I talk about their boobies.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Oh Christ, it’s those infernal women . CUT TO: Hundreds of incensed chanting women on bicycles w placards block the streets.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold my hand - squeeze my 17, 18, 19, 20, 21 - hand, hard as you like - not long now - stay calm -— actually, not too hard.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: 22, 23, 24, 25 - they’re coming quicker - oh my god we need to get there. Gianni honks repeatedly on the horn.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right. We’re getting out. You ready? And they step out into the street.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t think I can walk.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: There’s no need. I’1ll carry you.

dialogues.speaker: GIANNI
dialogues.text: I come behind with bag Mr Mark. And there’s a great rush of romantic music as, in true Officer and Gentleman-style, Mark lifts her into his arms

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I must be very heavy.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Nonsense, I don’t feel a thing! JUMP CUT to ten yards later. Gasping, red-faced, doubled over, Mark can’t go one step further.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good God, Bridget, you’re immense!

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I can’t help it!

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I think my lung’s collapsed, but this is not about me.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Contraction’s starting again! I’m going to have the baby in the street!

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Okay, we’ll walk for ten, rest for ten. And he hauls Bridget on towards the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is still carrying her. Almost on his knees...when Ja on his motorcycle, screeches to a halt. He gets off.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'll take it from here! Darcy hands Bridget over to Jack. He tries to carry her.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Holy shit - I think this is a two man job.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. HOSPITAL. LABOUR UNIT. NIGHT. 170
dialogues.text: Mark and Jack carry Bridget in through the doors. A MIDWI runs up with a wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: MIDWIFE
dialogues.text: Which of you is the father? Mark and Jack step forward.

dialogues.speaker: MARK/JACK
dialogues.text: (in unison) I am. The mid-wife looks confused, but ushers them into the delivery room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bridget is on her hands and knees on the birthing bed. Ma and Jack simultaneously rub her back. Two midwives busy themselves preparing the equipment. DR RAWLINGS enters the room and looks from JACK to MARK, smiles knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: DR RAWLINGS
dialogues.text: Ah, I was wondering how many fathers we might get today - full house! Bingo! (calm) OK Bridget, how are we going to do this? Epidural?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You can do this, a positive mental attitude is stronger than any drug, think away the pain.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Bollocks to that. I want everything - gas, air, injections, morphine -

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Bridget... Remember your yoga.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Fuck yoga!

dialogues.speaker: DR RAWLINGS
dialogues.text: Couldn’t agree more. It’s supposed to be relaxing but I spend my entire time worried that I’m going to let out a fart. Now, let me have a look at that cervix of yours. She lifts up Bridget’s gown and Jack can’t help but get a look at the ‘action area’. He looks queasy. A blood curdl scream comes from the woman giving birth in the room next door. DR RAWLINGS (CONT’D) Oh, good! CLOSE on Bridget’s relief. DR RAWLINGS (CONT’D) You're already at six centimetres so you can’t have any drugs at all.

dialogues.speaker: DR RAWLINGS
dialogues.text: You're too far on. Oooh another contraction. Bridget winces in excruciating pain. Jack and Mark wince Bridget winces. DR RAWLINGS (CONT’D) (to Jack and Mark) I’m not sure there is much to gain from you being at the coal face, if I’m honest. My ex-husband said it was like watching his favourite pub burn down. Another huge scream.

dialogues.speaker: MIDWIFE
dialogues.text: Maybe dad should go and fetch mum a cool flannel. Mark and Jack look confused, unsure which of them should there is a bit of awkwardness then Mark goes to get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark returns with a cool flannel in his hand, Jack grabs from him and places it on Bridget’s forehead, leaving Mar floundering and annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Bu...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You can do this, just think the pain away. As Jack gets closer, gently imploring her to manage the p she lifts her fist and punches him hard in the face, knoc him down.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Motherfuckers!

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Just think the pain away... Jack nurses his bleeding nose.

dialogues.speaker: GET OUT
dialogues.text: Unwilling to infuriate her more, the men share a look and both go to leave.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Make it stop, make the pain stop. (to the departing men)

dialogues.speaker: WHERE ARE YOU GOING
dialogues.text: Both men are at the door, look at each other and turn rou sheepishly making their way back towards the bed.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: It’s too painful! I can’t do this I just can’t.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Bridget lets out a blood curdling scream, she is clearly huge pain. Both men simultaneously put out their hands fo support, but as she screams, just as the pain appears tha might be too much and faced with the choice of the two me her life, impulsively, instinctively, she reaches for... MARK. Jack sees this and realizes that Bridget has made her cho As Bridget clings to Mark, the two men share a look. Jack gives a conciliatory and defeated nod then quietly, graciously, withdraws from the room. Oblivious to this, Bridget continues to squeeze Mark’s ha with superhuman might. He swallows his anguish and puts h face in front of Bridget so she can see him.  SHOOTING SCRIPT. Mark nods. 120

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You can! You can do it, Bridget! And we can do it together.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Look at what life’s thrown at you already. As he talks, Bridget grabs his arm and starts to bite int - it’s clearly extraordinarily painful, but Mark just gri his teeth register. and talks through the agony, barely letting it

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Christmas jumpers, massive pants, cheating boyfriends and repressed men who don’t deserve you. You’ve turned disasters into triumphs with your sheer joyful, infectious, indefatigable lust for life, time after time in succession. You've Managed your pregnancy almost entirely alone whilst having to deal with two juvenile men, a lunatic mother and...P...P...Poonani! He finally said it! She bites down harder. Mark conceals pain.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is just the last few moments and at the end of them, you’ll see your beautiful baby!

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: And what if the baby isn’t yours? What if he’s Jack’s?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: (no hesitation) Then I will love him anyway. Just like I love you, just the way you were; the way you are; and - no doubt - the way you always will be... Bridget looks at Mark through the red haze. He’s making sense. Then the next pain is upon her and she bows her he to it. She takes her teeth out of his now bloody arm, teethmarks apparent. He turns his back to her and lets out a massive silent scream.

dialogues.speaker: DR RAWLINGS
dialogues.text: You should probably go and get those seen to. I’1ll handle it from here. She ushers him out. DR RAWLINGS (CONT’D) Honestly... ‘think the pain away’... absolute nonsense, you’re squeezing out another human, I'd love to see them ‘think it away’. You're doing brilliantly, Bridget and you’re nearly there -

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I can’t -

dialogues.speaker: DR RAWLINGS
dialogues.text: (firm) Yes, you can actually, and I think you know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s the night of the election, and the recount has gone late into the night. Mum is on stage, next to all the oth candidates, awaiting the results. Una stands next to her.

dialogues.speaker: UNA
dialogues.text: The results are in. A formal looking official clutching a piece of paper approaches the microphone. Mum - tenses then braces herse

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: With three hundred and sixty-six of the votes, Mavis Rita Enderbury....

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Pamela- Dad fights his way to the stage, phone in hand.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: With three hundred and sixty-seven of the votes...

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Darling, it’s Bridget.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Pamela Margaret Jones.

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: Not now, Colin.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: It’s about the baby.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentleman, I hereby declare that the said Pamela Margaret Jones is duly elect... Mum leans over to whisper in his ear. The mic picks it up

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, you will have to excuse me. We’re about to become a grandmother! There are cheers from her supporters and she scurries off stage, pushing Una forward as she goes.

dialogues.speaker: MUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘1l leave you in the capable hands of my deputy, Una. Mum and Dad rush out of the hall, leaving the official an other candidates totally confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda is finishing up presenting the programme.
